pullRequest.title: Assign source columns to command toolbar buttons
pullRequest.bodyText:
Prior to this PR, commands accessing data in the Source Pane always used the active column's active editor. This was ok some of the time but caused issues when a user selected a command toolbar button in a column without moving focus to that column beforehand.
CommandSourceColumnToolbarButton was added to AppCommand to create and access toolbar buttons that have a specific source column assigned to them. Rather than firing its associated command on selection, it sets its source column to the active column and then fires the command. CommandSourceColumnMenuItem was added with similar functionality to handle menu items within a source column.
This PR adds some minor improvements to the source pane area as well. It moves some command assignments from SourceColumn to SourceColumnManager that do not vary by column. It also fixes some bugs that would improperly save the state of additional columns and cause issues when switching Enable Additional Columns on and off.

nodes.bodyText: Nit: formatting, { should be on its own line

Instead of keeping track of each registration, use a HandlerRegistrations to remember them and then unload them all at once. https://github.com/rstudio/rstudio/blob/master/src/gwt/src/org/rstudio/core/client/HandlerRegistrations.java

It feels a little weird that the AppCommand knows so much about source columns (these concepts should generally not be coupled except where necessary). What do you think about moving the source column bits into a separate package? You can could something like a SourceColumnCommand which wraps an AppCommand and adds the ability to generate the more contextual enable/disable states.

commit.message: fix formatting and switch individual handlers for HandlerRegistrations
begin implementing SourceColumnCommands
remove knowledge of source columns from AppCommand
modify command management so only the active column enables the AppCommand

nodes.bodyText:
Testing JavaScript objects for equality has a bunch of weird edge cases so I'd recommend avoiding it. For example the object could be cloned and the clone won't match, but they'll look like the same object in the debugger so it won't be obvious WHY they don't match!
How about storing sourceAppCommands_ as a HashMap, using the command ID (from command.getId()) plus the column name as a key? Then lookups will be faster, plus identity will be more reliable as you'll just need to check for existence in the map.

commit.message: use HashMap instead of HashSet

nodes.bodyText: Super-ultra-nitpicky: There are a bunch of methods in this class that are missing @Override.

commit.message: remove unused function and add in missing @Override
